Title: It's about time: Towards a dynamic account of natural vision

The TIME project proposes a paradigm shift in the study of natural vision, moving beyond traditional static and fragmented approaches to understanding visual perception. Our objective is to investigate vision as an active, semantic, and temporally dynamic process that is geared towards meaningful understanding. We will achieve this by exploring active information sampling in vision and analyzing visual processing across multiple timeframes.

Our interdisciplinary approach will combine non-invasive human brain imaging with multivariate analysis techniques and large-scale computational modelling. We will conduct a visual exploration of tens of thousands of rich, human-annotated natural scenes, develop novel multivariate analysis techniques, and create a new bio-inspired deep learning framework for active vision.

The goals of this project are twofold: to establish when, where, and how visual semantic understanding emerges in the brain, and to integrate information from the world in a continuously updating and dynamic decision process. By achieving these goals, we expect to make a significant impact on the field of vision research, providing new insights into complex neural processes in ecologically valid conditions and promoting a closer alignment between biological and synthetic vision. Ultimately, the TIME project has the potential to revolutionize our understanding of vision and its role in shaping our interaction with the world.

The TIME project revolutionizes the study of natural vision by shifting the focus from static, fragmented representations to a dynamic, active, and semantic process.
